instruction: How did the researchers map the distribution of redwoods at high spatial resolution?
Output: The researchers mapped the distribution of redwoods at high spatial resolution by using airborne imaging spectroscopy data collected over three redwood forests. They combined this data with field training data and applied a gradient boosted regression tree (GBRT) machine learning algorithm. The training data collected from the three sites showed that redwoods have distinct spectral signatures compared to other common tree species found in redwood forests. The researchers optimized the GBRT model for high performance and computational efficiency. The resulting model accurately mapped redwoods with a true positive rate of 81-98% and an overall accuracy of 90-98% in each of the study sites. The high-resolution maps showed variation in redwood abundance within a 1 square kilometer aggregation block, matching the spatial resolution of currently-available redwood distribution maps.

instruction: Can the distinct spectral signatures of redwoods, identified through airborne imaging spectroscopy data, be used as a superior method compared to traditional approaches in accurately mapping the distribution of redwood trees in California?
Output: Yes, the distinct spectral signatures of redwoods, identified through airborne imaging spectroscopy data, can be used as a superior method compared to traditional approaches in accurately mapping the distribution of redwood trees in California. The study mentioned in the text used airborne imaging spectroscopy data collected over three redwood forests, combined with field training data and a gradient boosted regression tree (GBRT) machine learning algorithm, to map the distribution of redwoods at a high spatial resolution of 2-meters. The resulting model was demonstrably accurate, with a true positive rate of 81-98% and an overall accuracy of 90-98% in mapping redwoods in each of the study sites. This high-resolution mapping approach provides a more detailed and reliable method for identifying the presence and abundance of redwood trees, which can greatly assist in research, conservation, and management efforts for redwoods in California.
